abstract.text: Initializes a vImage buffer with a specified width, height, and bits per pixel.

structure.
The height of the image.
The width of the image.
The number of bits in a pixel of image data. If
isn’t divisible by 8,
pads each row of pixels to a multiple of a byte. This ensures that two rows don’t share the same byte, and all rows start at the beginning of a byte.
The options to use when performing this operation.

This function provides two different operations, depending on whether you pass the
flag.
Without the
flag, this function initializes a

structure with memory that the vImage library sizes and aligns for the best performance. For example, the following code initializes a vImage buffer with the optimal memory size and alignment for a 10 x 5 image:
With the
flag, the function returns the memory alignment and overwrites the buffer’s
property with values that provide the best performance. For example, the following code calls
and uses the computed values to allocate an

code: // A negative value indicates an error.

inlineContent.text: In both cases, this function sets the buffer’s width, height, and row bytes properties.

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
A flag that prevents vImage from allocating additional storage.
The vImage function completed without error.
Initializes a vImage buffer with a specified width, height, and bits per pixel.
A type for the number of pixels.
An image buffer that stores an image’s pixel data, dimensions, and row stride.
The distance, in bytes, between the start of one pixel row and the next in an image, including any unused space between them.
Look up type aliases, data types, and constants the vImage library uses.
A raw pointer for accessing and manipulating untyped data.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
